results.title: Colour of war
results.creator_credit: Alastair Laurence, Lucy Carter, Carlton Television and Transworld International
results.brief_description: Almost all our recollections of the Second World War are in black and white. But years of research have unearthed hours of previously unseen colour film offering a completely new portrait of the war. The result is ‘Colour Of War’ a remarkable insight into the event that has shaped our modern world. Dramatic colour footage from as early as 1933 shows home movies of Adolf Hitler and his co-horts, the devastation wrought by the Blitz, life on the home front, D-Day and the Allied Invasion of France, British bombers defying German fighters, the horror of the Holocaust that greeted troops as they entered Germany and the jubilation of VE Day. With John Thaw’s narration and spoken accounts from the letters and diaries of those who fought, those who survived, and those the war claimed as victims, this three part documentary is an extraordinary remembrance.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Alastair Laurence, Lucy Carter, Carlton Television and Transworld International

results.title: Colour of war [DVD]
results.creator_credit: Alastair Laurence, Lucy Carter, Carlton Television and Transworld International
results.brief_description:
Almost all our recollections of the Second World War are in black and white. But years of research have unearthed hours of previously unseen colour film offering a completely new portrait of the war. The result is ‘Colour Of War’ a remarkable insight into the event that has shaped our modern world. Dramatic colour footage from as early as 1933 shows home movies of Adolf Hitler and his co-horts, the devastation wrought by the Blitz, life on the home front, D-Day and the Allied Invasion of France, British bombers defying German fighters, the horror of the Holocaust that greeted troops as they entered Germany and the jubilation of VE Day. With John Thaw’s narration and spoken accounts from the letters and diaries of those who fought, those who survived, and those the war claimed as victims, this three part documentary is an extraordinary remembrance.
1. ‘A new world order’ Reccollections of those involved during the pre-war turmoil of 1930s when the rhetoric of ideology and extremism was increasingly being heard. Highlights include combat footage of the Spanish Civil War, the coronation of King George VI in 1937, spectacular mass rallies in Germany and the Soviet Union and the images of the devastation of the Blitz in Great Britain.
2. ‘Total War’ Focuses on the period when the war reached a new, global intensity, beginning with the bombing of Pearl Harbor in December 1941 and ending in the Summer of 1944 with US Marines fighting bloody battles with the Japanese in the Pacific.
3. ‘Triumph and despair’ The experiences of British, American and Canadian soldiers, who made the historic crossing of the Channel, and who fought through The Battle of the Hedgerows to liberate Northern France, are heard through their letters and diaries. The fears and emotions expressed by American, French and Japanese soldiers and Japanese and German civilians are accompanied by footage of the fall of Berlin, the Battle of Okinawa, Kamikaze attacks and the devastation of the Atom bomb. This volume concludes with footage of the release of POWs, refugees and displaced people and reflects on the legacy of a war which cost 50 million lives.

Also available on VHS [313552], [313553], and [313554].

results.title: Colour bars
results.creator_credit: Fabio Cavadini, Mandy King and Auburn Community Development Network
results.brief_description: This non-observational documentary made for SBS Independent is about the lives of five young Australians of non-English Speaking Backgrounds. They were born or raised in Australia and have experienced the ups and downs of growing up in at least two cultures; that of their parents and the mainstream culture.

results.title: Colourful notions (TEFC)
results.brief_description: Colour vision must have evolved to serve some practical purpose. Dr. Edwin Lord has a new theory that colour is not the property of objects at all but the result of complex calculations which the brain performs to ensure that objects can be recognized under a wide range of light conditions

results.title: Color me lurid: the weird world of George Kuchar
results.creator_credit: George Kuchar, Argus Films and British Film Institute
results.brief_description: A compilation of underground filmmaker George Kuchar’s “crazed, revved-up and stripped down melodramas… perverse, funny but strangely poignant.” Twenty years before “Blue Velvet”, Kuchar and his twin brother Mike were obsessed with pop culture and kitsch. Part of the New York “underground”, they were unusual in wanting to make lavish melodramas featuring hand-painted titles, lurid colour and sound, tabloid-type tales, startling hair-dos and vivid costumes.
results.title_for_label: Color me lurid: the weird world of George Kuchar

results.title: Cold pizza
results.creator_credit: Larry Kent, Michael Rubbo, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: This is an engaging story of young enterprise, pitfalls, and eventual success. It is about two young Greek boys of Montreal who try to earn some extra money for a trip to their homeland by delivering pizzas. The misadventures they encounter, and how they surmount them all, make an amusing story full of youthful initiative. (Awards: Buenos Aires; Cork; San Antonio)
results.creator_credit_for_label: Larry Kent, Michael Rubbo, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: College
results.creator_credit: Buster Keaton, James W. Horne, Buster Keaton Productions and Joseph Schenck
results.brief_description: Buster goes to college and becomes sports obsessed when his lady love considers him less than manly. Spending a fortune on every imaginable piece of sporting apparatus, Buster is determined to muscle his way into her affections. This film is representative of Keatons madcap antics and incredible stunts with a grand comic finale which will leave the audience reeling.

results.title: Cold journey
results.creator_credit: Martin Defalco, George Pearson and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: A feature drama about a young Canadian Indian’s attempt to find a place for himself. It tells of the cultural shock of an educational system that teaches him to be a white man, and of his attempts to discover a way of life more meaningful to his Native culture and ancestry. It is a tragic story of unexpected pitfalls and disillusionment that are as cruel as the bitter wind that greets him on his cold and lonely journey. The film stars Buckley Petawabano, Johnny Yesno and Chief Dan George, and was shot on location with the people of Indian reserves and schools in northern Saskatchewan and Manitoba.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Martin Defalco, George Pearson and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: Cold Chisel: last stand
results.creator_credit: Tony Stevens, John McLean and Next Vision
results.brief_description: For 10 years Cold Chisel defied the trends of industry conventions and inspired a legion of loyal fans which elevated them to a status unmatched in the history of Australian rock’n’roll. ‘Last stand’ is a feature length film which combines the story of Cold Chisel’s career, with multi-camera coverage of their farewell concert at the Sydney entertainment Centre in 1983. The film features live performances of 16 classical Chisel songs, with excerpts from many more underscoring the behind-the-scenes and archival footage. Interviews are conducted with band members Jimmy Barnes, Ian Moss, Don Walker, Phil Small and Steve Prestwich, as well as other music industry colleagues. Features the following tracks: “Standing on the outside”, “Cheap wine”, “Rising sun”, “Khe sanh”, “Janelle”, “Twentieth century”, “You got nothing I want”, “Tomorrow”, “Star hotel”, “Choir girl”, “Bow river”, “Flame trees”, “Saturday night”, “Wild thing”, “Goodbye (Astrid goodbye)” and “Don’t let go”.
